message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of a painful ulcer at the end of the penis, with enlarged and tender lymph nodes, suggest chancroid. The negative VDRL rules out syphilis (Chancre), and Condyloma acuminatum and Lymphogranuloma venereum usually present with different symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The painful lesion with an erythematous base and ragged edges on the end of the penis and the presence of enlarged and tender lymph nodes suggest chancroid as the most likely diagnosis. The negative VDRL test rules out syphilis (Chancre) as a possible diagnosis. Condyloma acuminatum presents as a painless wart-like growth and Lymphogranuloma venereum typically presents with systemic symptoms such as fever and malaise.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The painful ulcerated sore on the end of the penis with an erythematous base and ragged edges, along with the enlarged and tender lymph nodes, suggests the diagnosis of chancroid. The negative VDRL excludes the diagnosis of syphilis, which presents with a painless chancre. Condyloma acuminatum presents with warts, and lymphogranuloma venereum presents with lymphadenopathy that is typically painless.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of a painful lesion that started as a tiny red bump and enlarged to an ulcerated sore with tender lymph nodes and negative VDRL suggests chancroid. Chancre would present with painless ulcer and Lymphogranuloma venereum would have positive VDRL. Condyloma acuminatum presents as warts rather than ulcers.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with a painful and ulcerated lesion on the end of his penis, along with enlarged and tender lymph nodes in the inguinal area. These findings are characteristic of chancroid, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. Chancre and Condyloma acuminatum do not generally present with such acute symptoms, and Lymphogranuloma venereum typically presents with a painless lesion and regional lymphadenopathy. The negative VDRL result rules out syphilis as a possibility.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including the painful ulcer with ragged edges and tender inguinal lymph nodes, suggest chancroid. The negative VDRL result eliminates syphilis (which presents with a painless ulcer, or chancre) and the absence of condyloma acuminatum (genital warts) rules out that option. Lymphogranuloma venereum may present with inguinal lymphadenopathy but usually has a painless primary lesion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including the painful sore with an erythematous base and ragged edges and enlarged and tender lymph nodes in the inguinal area, are consistent with chancroid. A negative VDRL result rules out syphilis (chancre) as the cause. Condyloma acuminatum usually presents as wart-like lesions and lymphogranuloma venereum typically causes lymph node inflammation in the groin area.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lesion is painful and has ragged edges, which suggests Chancroid. The presence of fluctuant and tender lymph nodes in the inguinal area is also consistent with this diagnosis. Chancre usually presents as a painless ulcer with a smooth base, while condyloma acuminatum presents as a papillomatous growth. Lymphogranuloma venereum is also typically painless and presents with inguinal lymphadenopathy but it typically has a primary lesion that is not painful.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including painful ulcer and tender lymph nodes with negative VDRL test, suggest chancroid, caused by the bacteria Haemophilus ducreyi. Chancre is painless and caused by Treponema pallidum. Condyloma acuminatum presents as warts and caused by HPV. Lymphogranuloma venereum causes inguinal lymphadenopathy and usually occurs in men who have sex with men.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of a painful ulcer with tender and fluctuant lymph nodes suggest Chancroid, which is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. Chancre also presents with an ulcer, but it is usually painless and does not involve the lymph nodes. Condyloma acuminatum presents as genital warts, and Lymphogranuloma venereum presents with systemic symptoms like fever and malaise. The negative VDRL rules out syphilis as a possible diagnosis.
